title: Binary Sequences as Functions
content:
A **binary sequence** is modeled as a function from natural numbers to booleans: `Nat -> Bool`. Each sequence assigns either `true` (1) or `false` (0) to every position.

These correspond to real numbers in $[0, 1]$ via binary expansion: the sequence $(b_0, b_1, b_2, \ldots)$ represents $0.b_0b_1b_2\ldots$ in binary.
mathContext:
$s : \mathbb{N} \to \{0, 1\}$

For example, the sequence $1, 0, 1, 0, 1, 0, \ldots$ represents $0.101010\ldots_2 = \frac{2}{3}$ in decimal.

title: The Diagonal Function
content:
Given any enumeration $f$ of binary sequences, we construct a **diagonal sequence** by:

1. Look at position $n$ of sequence $n$
2. Flip that bit (0 becomes 1, 1 becomes 0)

This ensures our new sequence differs from $f(n)$ at position $n$ for every $n$.
mathContext:
$\text{diagonal}(f)(n) = \neg f(n)(n)$

Visually:
```
f(0): [0] 1  1  0  ...
f(1):  1 [0] 0  1  ...
f(2):  0  0 [1] 0  ...
Diag:  1  1  0  ...  (flipped diagonal)
```

title: Diagonal Differs at Each Position
content:
The key lemma: our constructed diagonal sequence differs from $f(n)$ specifically at position $n$.

Since `diagonal f n = !(f n n)`, we have `diagonal f n != f n n` by the fact that `!b != b` for any boolean.

This one-line observation is the heart of the proof.
mathContext:
$	ext{diagonal}(f)(n) 
eq f(n)(n)$

Because $
eg b 
eq b$ for any boolean $b$.

title: Cantor's Diagonalization Theorem
content:
**For any function $f : \mathbb{N} \to \text{BinarySeq}$, there exists a sequence $s$ not in the range of $f$.**

In other words, no enumeration of binary sequences can be complete. There will always be a sequence we missed.

title: Constructing the Witness
content:
We exhibit the diagonal sequence as our witness. The `use` tactic provides this existential witness.

Now we must prove this sequence differs from every $f(n)$.
mathContext: Take $s = \text{diagonal}(f)$, then show $\forall n, f(n) \neq s$.

title: Deriving the Contradiction
content:
Suppose for contradiction that $f(n) = \text{diagonal}(f)$ for some $n$.

Then at position $n$: $f(n)(n) = \text{diagonal}(f)(n)$.

But $\text{diagonal}(f)(n) = \neg f(n)(n)$ by definition.

So $f(n)(n) = \neg f(n)(n)$, which is impossible for any boolean.

Contradiction! Therefore $f(n) \neq \text{diagonal}(f)$ for all $n$.

title: Reals Are Uncountable
content:
The classic formulation: there is no surjective function from $\mathbb{N}$ to the binary sequences (equivalently, to $\mathbb{R}$).

This follows immediately from Cantor's theorem: if $f$ were surjective, every sequence would be in its range, but we just showed one isn't.
mathContext:
$\nexists f : \mathbb{N} \to 2^{\mathbb{N}}$ such that $f$ is surjective.

Equivalently: $|\mathbb{N}| < |\mathbb{R}|$

anchor.contains: The diagonal function: given an enumeration of seq

title: Proof of Uncountability
content:
Assume for contradiction that some surjective $f$ exists.

By Cantor's theorem, there exists $s$ with $f(n) \neq s$ for all $n$.

But surjectivity says every $s$ equals some $f(n)$.

These contradict: $s = f(n)$ but also $f(n) \neq s$.
mathContext:
$f$ surjective $\Rightarrow \forall s, \exists n, f(n) = s$

Cantor: $\exists s, \forall n, f(n) \neq s$

Contradiction!

title: Cantor's Power Set Theorem
content:
The general version: for **any** set $S$, there is no surjection from $S$ to its power set $\mathcal{P}(S)$.

This proves $|S| < |\mathcal{P}(S)|$ for all sets, establishing an infinite hierarchy of cardinalities.

For finite sets: $|\mathcal{P}(S)| = 2^{|S|}$. For infinite sets: the power set is strictly larger.

title: The Diagonal Set
content:
The diagonal construction for sets: $D = \{x \in S : x \notin f(x)\}$.

This is the set of elements that are *not* in their own image under $f$.

This is exactly Russell's paradox applied to $f$! If $f$ were surjective, $D = f(a)$ for some $a$. But then: is $a \in D$?
mathContext:
$D = \{x : x \notin f(x)\}$

If $D = f(a)$:
- $a \in D \iff a \notin f(a) = D$ — contradiction!

title: Visualizing the Diagonal
content:
The comment shows the diagonal argument visually. Imagine an infinite table where row $n$ is sequence $f(n)$.

The diagonal elements are $f(0)(0), f(1)(1), f(2)(2), \ldots$

Flipping each gives a sequence that differs from:
- Row 0 at column 0
- Row 1 at column 1
- Row $n$ at column $n$

So the flipped diagonal cannot be any row in the table!
